doc.title: European Rates Primer
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/European Rates Primer Overview of the SSA market - updateEuropean Rates Primer Overview of the SSA market - update_2025-08-29

passages.text: This is an updated version of our SSA primer from July 2025, including more complete lists of issuers and additional information on outstandings by currency.

In this primer, we cover a growing part of the Euro Area and international fixed income sphere, the SSA market (Supranationals, sub- sovereigns and agencies). SSA bonds can be seen as attractive investments with yield pick- up over government bonds and often equivalent credit risks. However, the relatively lower levels of liquidity can also cause unwanted exposure during periods of high volatility and/or risk- off.

The supply patterns of the Euro Area SSA market are in many ways similar to those of EGB issuers, with front loading, presence along the whole curve, and growing net supply as the ECB has stopped QE. However, differences include the fact that most SSAs issue only via syndications and that they are active in multiple currencies. This allows them to broaden their investor base and take advantage of attractive funding opportunities.

The major investor types in SSA markets are banks, fund managers, pension & insurance, as well as foreign official institutions and central banks. Their preference varies across the curve and the attractiveness of price levels are measured differently. For many EUR- denominated SSAs, the ECB also represented a very significant buyer with its large- scale Quantitative Easing (QE) programmes over 2015- 22. With Quantitative Tightening now under way, the ability and willingness of other investors to now absorb the growing net supply will be important for market pricing and relative valuations.
Introduction to SSAs 2  Euro Area SSAs: Supply 9  Euro Area SSAs: Demand 15  Global issuers 17

Trading ideas and investment strategies discussed herein may give rise to significant risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should have experience in relevant markets and the financial resources to absorb any losses arising from applying these ideas or strategies.  BofA Securities does and seeks to do business with issuers covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.  Refer to important disclosures on page 20 to 22.
Rates Research Europe
European Rates Research  MLI (UK)
See Team Page for List of Analysts
See page 19 for a Glossary to terms and abbreviations used in the report.

While SSA issuers are often grouped together as one, their institutional set- up can vary. Their different objectives, capital- base, and type of ownership/guarantees impact both their funding needs and credit worthiness, and thereby their pricing. Below, we describe the set- up of the three different SSA types and provide a list of basic information about all major SSAs. We then discuss supply and demand patterns for Euro Area SSAs.

Supranationals (supras) are institutions that are owned or established by two or more governments, that can raise money in capital markets in order to fund the needs or projects they set out to finance. Their capital base typically consists of paid- in capital by shareholders. In almost all cases, this is further supported by callable capital that the supranational can obtain if needed (with some exceptions). The joint ownership by governments and often substantial capital base, including the callable capital, typically results in strong perceived credit worthiness. Additionally, their issued debt tends to qualify as High Quality Liquid Assets (HQLA) level 1 under LCR (exceptions exists).

Agencies are institutions that are typically owned / guaranteed fully or partially by one government, and exist to serve the needs of the state, with often more narrowly scoped responsibility relative to Supranationals. As they are generally closely linked to the state, and have either implicit or explicit guarantees, their credit ratings are often the equivalent to the sovereign's. However, the difference in implicit and explicit guarantees, as well as the rules behind potential liquidation and fulfilment of the agencies' obligations can impact the risk- weighting, LCR status, as well as prices.

Sub- sovereigns are public non- national entities such as regions, provinces, or municipalities. They are able to issue bonds in public markets in different currencies and maturities to fund their budget needs. The biggest share of supply comes from German Lander, but most Euro Area sovereigns also have sub- sovereigns issuing debt. In this note, we focus less on Sub- Sovereigns.

Overall, all SSAs taken together represent a market size equivalent to that of European Govt bonds (EGBs) and around \(40\%\) the size of the UST (see Exhibit 1 with volumes outstanding globally across currencies - expressed in USD). Euro area regions and agencies together represent the largest category, with volumes focused in EUR (see Exhibit 2, displaying the currency composition of the outstanding bonds in each category - the "Others" currency = mainly CAD for Canadian agencies and Yen for Japanese ones).

The European Commission (EU bonds) is the second largest individual issuer, after the US Federal Home Loan. It is set to surpass the latter within the next two years. We
introduce it in detail below, before listing all major supranationals & European agencies in Exhibit 4.

EU bonds issued by the European Commission are not new, with EUR-denominated issues already existing in the 1990s to fund loans for financial assistance to Eastern Europe in particular. The 2009-12 banking and sovereign crisis led the EU to ramp up its issuance to also support some Euro Area countries (e.g., Portugal and Ireland). But it is the launch of two new programmes to deal with the COVID-19 shock (SURE and NGEU – Exhibit 3), that structurally changed the EU since the SSA space from a small issuer with around €50bn outstanding in 2019 to the largest European SSA, with current outstanding of more than €650bn, which is likely to grow beyond €800bn by end of next year.
Issuance ramped up as SURE and NGEU were created on the back of the COVID shock

Most funds raised by the EU are for the provision of loans. Only a portion of the NGEU funding is for grants (up to €360bn). If a loan beneficiary country doesn't service its debt (which has never happened to date), the EU budget guarantees that the EU timely honours its own interest payments / debt repayment obligations. To this end, the Commission can make available its cash buffer, re-prioritise budgetary expenditure and, if needed, draw additional resources from member states, using the budgetary margin available. Ultimately, member states will be liable if the EU budget is insufficient. As a result, the EU has a high rating (AAA/AA+) and is generally able to fund itself at lower rates than most European Union governments, allowing it to lend to sovereigns at more attractive levels than the sovereign's funding rates in the market.

For 2025, the EU plans to issue €160bn, with €70bn coming in the second half of the year. Beyond next year, borrowing needs by the EU are more ambiguous as the NGEU comes to an end and other programs will take centre stage. The Security Action for Europe (SAFE) will be one of the primary funding needs as the EU looks to provide up to €150bn to member states. There will also be funding needs to support Ukraine.

In addition to large issuance volumes, the EU supply process differs from that of other Euro Area SSAs in a few ways: (1) the EU provides a more detailed bi-annual funding plan, communicating not only total funding needs, but also indicative dates of when issuance is planned and indications of the sectors where new issuance will concentrate; (2) the EU uses auctions too, not just syndications to sell debt; and (3) their issuance is less seasonal throughout the year, with less distinct front loading.

Starting from 2020, aggregate gross supply in all currencies from Euro Area SSAs has increased markedly. While agencies and supras may have stepped up their gross supply marginally, the key difference is the ramp- up of supply by the European Commision (EU) (see Exhibit 6). The EU has a variety of programs it funds, but the largest and most significant is its NGEU package. At current levels, the EU now issues more than all other European supranational institutions combined. That said, while most Euro Area SSAs can issue in the currency of their choice, the EU, as well as the supranational EFSF and a few agencies (e.g., France's Unedic) only issue bonds in EUR.

A distinct market feature from 2015 was the ECB's purchases of bonds for their QE programs. Euro Area SSAs were included in the purchase programmes, and considerable amounts of supply was thus taken out of private investors hands. Supply net of redemptions and QE flows, which equals the net supply that needs to be absorbed by private investors each year, was thus very low and often negative during the years of ECB's QE program. However, as the ECB has now stopped re-investing maturing debt, this trend is reversing, and net supply is instead reaching record highs as the EU also ramped up its issuance over the last few years. As the ECB only purchased bonds denominated in EUR, this large variation in net supply is a EUR bond story.
We project record EUR-denominated net supply of €250bn in 2025, representing a 25% increase compared to 2024, which was itself a record high year (see Exhibit 9).

In contrast to most Euro Area sovereigns issuing bonds, SSAs will meet their funding needs in a variety of different currencies (see Exhibit 10). This helps enhance long- term stability of the investor base and allows short- term optimisation of funding costs. As more investors can be reached by issuing in multiple currencies, it effectively broadens the investor base, and may increase aggregate demand for the bonds on offer. It can also reduce re- funding risks as issuers limit their reliance on specific investor types to meet funding needs. In addition, SSAs can take advantage of relative funding attractiveness in different currencies to lower their issuance costs.
Exhibit 10: Currency breakdown of EA SSAs (ex EU) More than \(40\%\) of the supply is done outside of EUR, but
Exhibit 11: USD as a % of total (3m MA) vs "minus" 5y Xccy basis Greater issuance in USD when FX-Sofr widens (\*)
Source:Dealogic\\*\\* Chart presents the Xccy basis multiplied by -1.
Issuers tend not to withdraw completely or expand heavily into different currencies from one year to the other. However, there can be over- or under- reliance on some currencies.

Excluding the EU, which only issues in EUR, Euro Area SSAs generally issue on aggregate between 50- 60% in EUR, 20- 40% in USD, 5- 10% in GBP, 1- 3% in AUD, and the rest in various other currencies (Exhibit 10). Euro Area SSAs can and often will adjust the composition from one year to the other depending on the attractiveness of funding levels. In addition to supply and demand levels, the cost of FX swapping the flows

becomes an integral part of the perceived attractiveness, with a wider basis improving the funding costs when FX is swapped into EUR (Exhibit 11). So far in 2025, the share of issuance in EUR and GBP has increased vs 2024, while USD reliance has marginally decreased.

Euro area SSAs tend to frontload supply in the first quarter of the year, with about 30- 45% of total yearly supply conducted in that quarter, with generally 40- 50% of total supply split between the second and third quarter, which leaves them with much lighter needs in Q4 (about 10- 20% of supply), primarily filled in October and November (see Exhibit 12). The larger supply volumes at the start of the year are primarily due to higher levels of demand during this period. There are several factors that can impact the seasonality of supply from one year to the other, including but not limited to, level of demand, attractiveness of funding rates, expectations of future changes in interest rates, supply of other SSA and non- SSA issuers, and specific risk events.

For European SSAs, excluding the EU, there is another important factor. As the EU issues large volumes and spreads out its supply more evenly throughout the calendar year, there is risk of insufficient demand for other issuers as the year progresses. Thus, they must adjust to optimise their funding abilities. This could be one reasons for the stronger front- loading activity (ex EU) in 2023- 24, with lower issuance during early summer and at year- end (see Exhibit 13).
Exhibit 12: EA all SSAs monthly distribution in EUR Issuance in EUR is relatively balanced throughout the year
Exhibit 13: EA SSAs ex EU monthly distribution in EUR When excluding the EU, the front loading become more pronounced

The seasonality of Euro Area SSA issuance in USD is similar to that in EUR when excluding the EU, albeit with moderately greater front loading. In GBP the front loading is much more pronounced. One reason for this is that the UK fiscal year starts in April, thus resulting in more limited Gilt supply in January and therefore greater availability of demand for GBP issuance by SSAs. Also (resulting from this seasonality) there are typically large SSA redemptions in Dec- Jan that need to be refinanced.
Exhibit 14: EA all SSAs monthly distribution in USD 2025 front loading is lesser than in 2024
Exhibit 15: EA all SSAs monthly distribution in GBP Front loading is greater in GBP issuance

To further stabilise their long- term funding needs, SSAs issue bonds in various tenors. Similar to issuing in more than one currency, this broadens their investor base, lessens their refunding risks, and allows them to take advantage of attractive parts of the curve.

The majority of Euro Area SSA supply has in most years come in the 1- 3y and 4- 6y sectors, and when adding 7- 9y and 10- 12y \(+80\%\) of total supply is typically filled. The variance from year to year is attributable to multiple factors, and one of those is the shape of the curve. As an example, the general curve flattening since 2018, as measured by Euribor 5s20s, has coincided with an increase of long- end supply. During the years 2014- 18, on the other hand, when the curve was steeper, supply was larger in Exhibit 16: EA SSA issuance maturity split, all currencies Values include supply from the EU
Exhibit 17: EA SSA issuance maturity split, EUR Front loading is greater in GBP issuance

Issuing across the curve broadens the investor base as different investor types are typically active in different parts of the curve. Key investors on the shorter end are banks and reserve managers who require liquid, less volatile securities. Further out on the curve, fund managers become an increasingly more important investor, while on the very long- end pension and insurance funds typically dominate the flows. To avoid becoming dependent on one investor group, SSAs can thus issue bonds with various maturities.

Furthermore, if demand is particularly strong from a certain investor base, this can offer an opportunity to issue more of a certain tenor. This may partly explain why the percentage of EUR issuance in 1- 3y and 4- 6y has been relatively large in 2024 and so far in 2025, following large demand from banks. It can also explain the changes in 2015- 2023, with the presence of the ECB. At the end of 2024 the average maturity of ECB holdings of supranational bonds was 8.05 years. To take advantage of the significant purchasing power of the ECB, SSAs could issue EUR- denominated bonds across the whole curve. Alongside the curve flattening, the ability to rely on ECB purchases may explain the reduced issuance share of EUR issuance in the 1- 3y sector after 2015 and increased issuance of long end bonds, exemplified by the +20y sector (Exhibit 17).

During the years of relatively low short end supply in EUR from Euro Area SSAs, the percentage of short end supply in USD picked up instead. Similarly, when long end supply in EUR increased, especially in the years 2016- 18, USD long end supply fell. Thus, the overall change in maturity is less pronounced when observing total supply in all currencies compared to changes in currency- specific supply.
Exhibit 18: EA SSA issuance maturity split, USD Less relative amounts of supply in the 1-3y in recent years
Exhibit 19: EA SSA issuance maturity split, GBP Maturities are short in GBP but vary significantly year to year

As previously mentioned, varying attractiveness in funding levels can skew the currency split for SSA funding needs, but this typically does not happen across the board. Instead, the attractiveness in issuing in various currencies is very sector dependent.

To gauge this and estimate potential future supply, we like to look at the attractiveness of funding levels in different currencies across sectors for large and very opportunistic issuers. European Investment Bank (EIB) and KFW are the typical names we start with (see Exhibit 20 and Exhibit 21).
Exhibit 20: EIB bond EUR ASW equivalent level in different ccy, est. Attractive issuance levels in short end GBP
Source: Bloomberg, BofA Global Research. As of YE 2024
Exhibit 21: KFW bond EUR ASW equivalent level in different ccy, est. Attractive issuance levels in short end GBP
Source: Bloomberg, BofA Global Research. As of YE 2024
Despite the SSAs' ability to issue in various tenors and currencies, there are still trends that have remained consistent over the last decade. For supply in USD, the average

maturity of issuance is significantly lower. One reason for this is that a primary source of demand is foreign reserve managers, who usually hold a large proportion of USD assets and are not usually swapping attractive EUR assets into synthetic USD exposure. Thus, issuing USD- denominated short- term bonds becomes a necessity if they want to maintain this investor base. However, foreign reserve managers have also been reallocating their capital out of USD in recent years, which coincides interestingly with a fall in 1- 3y USD issuance.

In GBP, the maturity split is more sporadic, suggesting that SSAs' supply in this currency is more opportunistic. However, it remains clear that the absolute majority of supply each year is in the 1- 3y and 4- 6y maturity buckets. A key source of demand in GBP is banks, which prefer to buy in this part of the curve given ASW levels. As there is almost no UK SSA issuers, Euro Area names can be an attractive option for banks looking for a pick- up relative to gilts. For 2025, the attractive funding levels in GBP in short tenors partly explain the relatively large volumes of GBP issuance, and the focus on shorter tenors.

As they often offer a pick- up in yield over government bonds while having typically high credit ratings in line with sovereigns, SSAs can be an attractive investment opportunity for some investors. Supranational bonds also count as HQLA, and it also tends to be the case for agencies, with a few exceptions. The challenge for SSAs, however, is their more limited liquidity, which creates downside risk when selling is required in risk- off periods.
In recent years, demand for SSA bonds has been increasing, as indicated by the book sizes of yearly syndications done by EIB and KFW (Exhibit 22 and Exhibit 23).
Exhibit 22: EIB 10y EUR benchmark A strong order book to start the year
Exhibit 23: KFW 10y EUR benchmark Record book size for KFW
Source: Bond Radar \\*February instead of January

There are various types of investors who allocate capital to SSAs, but for this primer we categorise them as banks (including both bank treasuries and bank ALM divisions), institutional investors (primarily pension funds, insurance companies, and asset managers, however more granular detail is provided where available), as well as foreign central banks & official institutions. They can all be present on different parts of the
curve and in different currencies, but there are distinct differences in their overall demand profiles.

Banks (banks and bank treasuries) are a key source of demand for shorter maturity bonds, primarily below the 10y sector as liquidity and duration risk are key factors impacting their investment positions. The price attractiveness tends to be determined by the difference between the yield of the bond and an interest rate swap of the same maturity. As the swaps rate is derived by banks' quoted borrowing costs, the spread to swaps is a good measure of the potential interest rate differential from which banks can profit when investing in SSAs. Additionally, as banks' liabilities are often floating or short dated, banks may also hedge their duration risk by paying fixed in a swap. As they hedge out the duration risk, the change in value of their overall position instead becomes the spread between the two instruments, which makes it a key variable to monitor.
Syndication allocations over the last five years show that banks have generally been allocated a larger share of issuance (see: Exhibit 24, Exhibit 25 and Exhibit 26).

Institutional investors (asset managers, pension funds & insurance) tend to be more active in longer- dated securities, in part due to their long- dated liabilities. The relative yield pick- up in SSA vs government bonds appears to play an important role for them. The general tightening in SSA- govie spreads in recent years could therefore, in part, explain their reduced allocation share of SSA syndications over recent years.

Foreign central banks & official institutions are another key investor group. Like banks, they prefer investing in shorter- dated maturities. While they look at yield levels and potential returns, central banks are first and foremost focused on ensuring capital preservation and good liquidity levels. This means that on aggregate they typically focus on high- rated issuers. In the last two years, we can see an increased allocation of central banks and official institutions at EIB and KFW syndications, but not for CADES. One reason for this can be the decreased creditworthiness of France, the ultimate guarantor of CADES, which has resulted in downgrades of their credit ratings.
Exhibit 24: EIB Investor split 10y EUR Institutional investors gradually receiving less
Exhibit 25: KFW Investor split 10y EUR Banks are becoming the primary investor
Exhibit 26: CADES Investor split 5y EUR Banks became majority investor type at \(58\%\)

Another way to analyse demand for SSAs is to look at the geographical allocation at syndications. In line with the increased allocation to foreign central banks and official institutions, we find an increased allocation to investors in Asia and the "rest of the world" in EIB's and KFW's syndications of the last two years. The same cannot be said for CADES (see: Exhibit 27, Exhibit 28 and Exhibit 29). Instead, CADES allocations have increasingly been geared towards eurozone investors.

Another key segment of the SSA market is global supranationals. Here we cover the three crucial funding institutions of the World Bank Group: International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), the International Finance Corporation (IFC) and the International Development Association (IDAWBG) and regional supranationals outside of the Euro Area (full list with outstanding amounts and current FY supply targets are in Exhibit 30). Despite the regional focus of the latter supranationals, their ownership is typically global, a key distinction from the EIB and the EU.

Compared to Euro Area SSAs, the global Supranationals from the World Bank Group do not have as a distinct front- loading of supply (Exhibit 31). The main reason is their different fiscal years, starting in July and ending in June. While supply in January remains significant as large demand forces are present at the start of the year, so is supply in the third quarter and especially September. During May and June, when their fiscal year is coming to an end, supply tends to be smaller. For regional supranationals, front- loading is comparable to Euro Area SSA supply (see: Exhibit 32).

Exhibit 31: Seasonality issuance of World Bank Group issuers (IBRD, IDAWBG, and IFC), % of the yearly supply completed each month. The front loading of supply in Jan-Feb is limited, with high supply in Jul-Oct

From a currency perspective, the USD dominates issuance by global and regional supranationals. At the same time, compared to Euro Area SSAs, they have a greater share of issuance outside the top currencies - see "Other" in Exhibit 33 and Exhibit 34.

One reason for the large share of USD issuance is that non- EA supranationals will generally have a large portion of their assets in USD, and to limit currency risk they tend to issue in USD. The other reason is, of course, the vast amount of capital ready to absorb the high- quality USD denominated debt, which provides some credit diversification and pick- up vs UST.

We note, however, that the rise in supply by IDA since 2020 has resulted in an increased share of EUR supply for the World bank group issuers (with IDA having been more geared towards EUR issuance than IBRD and IFC - Exhibit 30).
The attractiveness of GBP issuance has also let to an increased share of GBP supply for regional supranationals outside the Euro Area, especially since last year (Exhibit 34).
